{"abstract": "President Robert Mugabe of Zimbabwe, below, said he plans to take control of the nation\u2019s diamond mines in response to allegations of smuggling and a diamond rush in the eastern district of Marange. Zimbabwe has two diamond mines, one known as Murowa, owned by Rio Tinto and RioZim, and the other as River Ranch, which is held by private investors. \u201cOnly government will mine diamonds,\u201d Mr. Mugabe said in a televised interview on Tuesday. It is unclear whether Mr. Mugabe\u2019s pronouncement will be made law, said David Murangari, chief executive of the Chamber of Mines, a business association that represents most mining companies in the country. Andrew Cranswick, chief executive of African Consolidated Resources, criticized the measure. \u201cIf the state takeover of diamond mines is passed into law, it will destroy diamond exploration in this country,\u201d he said.", "web_url": "https://www.nytimes.com/2007/02/22/business/worldbusiness/22fobriefs-TAKEOVEROFDI_BRF.html", "snippet": "President Robert Mugabe of Zimbabwe, below, said he plans to take control of the nation\u2019s diamond mines in response to allegations of smuggling and a diamond rush in the eastern district of Marange. {"abstract": "Shares of Alcan, the world\u2019s second-biggest aluminum producer, rose the most in two weeks on speculation Brazil\u2019s Compahnia Vale do Rio Doce may make a takeover bid. {"abstract": "The Rio Tinto Group, a mining company that is a major producer of coal, will join BP to develop power generation plants that will pump their carbon dioxide emissions underground to help curb global warming. {"abstract": "Robert M. Godsell, the chief executive of AngloGold Ashanti, plans to retire after running the company since its creation in 1998 and helping it become the world\u2019s third-biggest gold producer with operations in 10 countries. Mr. Godsell, left, who will step down on September 30, will be succeeded by Mark Cutifani, the chief operating officer of Companhia Vale do Rio Doce\u2019s nickel unit, AngloGold said. Mr. Godsell, 54, was the chief executive of Anglo American\u2019s gold and uranium division from 1995 before taking over as head of AngloGold, a company formed by a merger of Anglo American\u2019s separately traded gold companies and the gold assets of Minorco. Other acquisitions included Ashanti Goldfields of Ghana.", "web_url": "https://www.nytimes.com/2007/08/01/business/worldbusiness/01fobriefs-ANGLOGOLD821_BRF.html", "snippet": "Robert M. Godsell, the chief executive of AngloGold Ashanti, plans to retire after running the company since its creation in 1998 and helping it become the world\u2019s third-biggest gold producer with operations in 10 countries. Mr. Godsell, left, who will step down on September 30, will be succeeded by Mark Cutifani, the chief operating officer of Companhia Vale do Rio Doce\u2019s nickel unit, AngloGold said. Mr. Godsell, 54, was the chief executive of Anglo American\u2019s gold and uranium division from 1995 before taking over as head of AngloGold, a company formed by a merger of Anglo American\u2019s separately traded gold companies and the gold assets of Minorco. Other acquisitions included Ashanti Goldfields of Ghana.", "print_section": "C", "print_page": "7", "source": "The New York Times", "multimedia": [], "headline": {"main": "South Africa: Anglogold\u2019s Chief to Retire", "kicker": "World Business Briefing", "content_kicker": null, "print_headline": "South Africa: Anglogold\u2019s Chief To Retire", "name": null, "seo": null, "sub": null}, "keywords": [{"name": "glocations", "value": "South Africa", "rank": 1, "major": "N"}, {"name": "subject", "value": "Gold", "rank": 2, "major": "N"}, {"name": "subject", "value": "Metals and Minerals", "rank": 3, "major": "N"}, {"name": "subject", "value": "Appointments and Executive Changes", "rank": 4, "major": "N"}], "pub_date": "2007-08-01T04:00:00+0000", "document_type": "article", "news_desk": "Business", "section_name": "Business Day", "subsection_name": "World Business", "byline": {"original": "By Bloomberg News", "person": [{"firstname": "Bloomberg", "middlename": null, "lastname": "News", "qualifier": null, "title": null, "role": "reported", "organization": "", "rank": 1}], "organization": null}, "type_of_material": "Brief", "_id": "nyt://article/7ab6d833-ab2c-513c-9018-d03debbf9417", "word_count": 118, "uri": "nyt://article/7ab6d833-ab2c-513c-9018-d03debbf9417"}

{"abstract": "European Union regulators extended an investigation into BHP Billiton\u2019s hostile bid for the Rio Tinto Group because of \u201cserious doubts\u201d about the combination.", "web_url": "https://www.nytimes.com/2008/07/05/business/worldbusiness/05bizbriefs-EUROPEDELAYS_BRF.html", "snippet": "European Union regulators extended an investigation into BHP Billiton\u2019s hostile bid for the Rio Tinto Group because of \u201cserious doubts\u201d about the combination.", "lead_paragraph": "European Union regulators extended an investigation into BHP Billiton\u2019s hostile bid for the Rio Tinto Group because of \u201cserious doubts\u201d about the combination, which would control more than a third of the world\u2019s iron ore production. {"abstract": "The Chinese government\u2019s largest investment ever in a Western company, a proposed $19.5 billion stake in the Australian-British mining giant Rio Tinto Group, collapsed early Friday.", "web_url": "https://dealbook.nytimes.com/2009/06/05/turning-to-bhp-billiton-rio-tinto-scraps-china-deal/", "snippet": "The Chinese government\u2019s largest investment ever in a Western company, a proposed $19.5 billion stake in the Australian-British mining giant Rio Tinto Group, collapsed early Friday.", "lead_paragraph": "The Chinese government\u2019s largest planned investment ever in a Western company, a proposed $19.5 billion stake in the Australian-British mining giant Rio Tinto Group, collapsed early Friday, dealing a blow both to China\u2019s global corporate ambitions and to its efforts to gain clout in the natural resources market, The New York Times\u2019s David Barboza and Michael Wines reported.", "source": "The New York Times", "multimedia": [], "headline": {"main": "Turning to BHP Billiton, Rio Tinto Scraps China Deal", "kicker": "DealBook", "content_kicker": null, "print_headline": "", "name": null, "seo": null, "sub": null}, "keywords": [], "pub_date": "2009-06-05T05:46:31+0000", "document_type": "article", "news_desk": "Business", "section_name": "Business Day", "byline": {"original": "By Dealbook", "person": [{"firstname": "Dealbook", "middlename": null, "lastname": "", "qualifier": null, "title": null, "role": "reported", "organization": "", "rank": 1}], "organization": null}, "type_of_material": "News", "_id": "nyt://article/ace187b3-b864-57ae-8870-b6f7eb4b9865", "word_count": 1096, "uri": "nyt://article/ace187b3-b864-57ae-8870-b6f7eb4b9865"}

{"abstract": "The leading steel industry group in China has come out against a joint venture consolidating iron ore assets of BHP Billiton and Rio Tinto in Australia.", "web_url": "https://dealbook.nytimes.com/2009/06/08/chinese-steel-group-opposes-bhp-rio-deal/", "snippet": "The leading steel industry group in China has come out against a joint venture consolidating iron ore assets of BHP Billiton and Rio Tinto in Australia.", "lead_paragraph": "The leading steel industry group in China has come out against a joint venture consolidating iron ore assets of BHP Billiton and Rio Tinto in Australia, the influential Caijing Magazine reported.", "source": "The New York Times", "multimedia": [], "headline": {"main": "Chinese Steel Group Opposes BHP-Rio Deal", "kicker": "DealBook", "content_kicker": null, "print_headline": "", "name": null, "seo": null, "sub": null}, "keywords": [], "pub_date": "2009-06-08T11:28:43+0000", "document_type": "article", "news_desk": "Business", "section_name": "Business Day", "byline": {"original": "By Dealbook", "person": [{"firstname": "Dealbook", "middlename": null, "lastname": "", "qualifier": null, "title": null, "role": "reported", "organization": "", "rank": 1}], "organization": null}, "type_of_material": "News", "_id": "nyt://article/f859f048-1492-5343-9346-df034d189d02", "word_count": 469, "uri": "nyt://article/f859f048-1492-5343-9346-df034d189d02"}

{"abstract": "Some observers were skeptical about claims that China\u2019s decision to hold an Australian executive from Rio Tinto on suspicion of stealing state secrets was unrelated to commerce.", "web_url": "https://dealbook.nytimes.com/2009/07/09/timing-suspicious-for-chinas-detention-of-rio-staff/", "snippet": "Some observers were skeptical about claims that China\u2019s decision to hold an Australian executive from Rio Tinto on suspicion of stealing state secrets was unrelated to commerce.", "lead_paragraph": "When Australia\u2019s foreign minister said  he did not believe that China\u2019s decision to detain a Rio Tinto executive was related to commercial matters, some industry observers expressed skepticism.", "source": "The New York Times", "multimedia": [], "headline": {"main": "Timing Suspicious for China\u2019s Detention of Rio Staff", "kicker": "DealBook", "content_kicker": null, "print_headline": "", "name": null, "seo": null, "sub": null}, "keywords": [], "pub_date": "2009-07-09T09:43:27+0000", "document_type": "article", "news_desk": "Business", "section_name": "Business Day", "byline": {"original": "By Dealbook", "person": [{"firstname": "Dealbook", "middlename": null, "lastname": "", "qualifier": null, "title": null, "role": "reported", "organization": "", "rank": 1}], "organization": null}, "type_of_material": "News", "_id": "nyt://article/b539144a-608e-5cdb-abd8-662c9e3455bd", "word_count": 616, "uri": "nyt://article/b539144a-608e-5cdb-abd8-662c9e3455bd"}

{"abstract": "Beijing\u2019s detention of four Rio Tinto employees has rocked the global iron ore industry, strained China-Australia relations and could have a chilling effect on foreign businesses doing deals in China.", "web_url": "https://dealbook.nytimes.com/2009/07/13/china-rattles-investors-with-detentions-of-executives/", "snippet": "Beijing\u2019s detention of four Rio Tinto employees has rocked the global iron ore industry, strained China-Australia relations and could have a chilling effect on foreign businesses doing deals in China.", "lead_paragraph": "On July 5, officials from China\u2019s Ministry of State Security took four employees of the Anglo-Australian mining giant Rio Tinto into custody here.", "source": "The New York Times", "multimedia": [], "headline": {"main": "China Rattles Investors With Detention of Executives", "kicker": "DealBook", "content_kicker": null, "print_headline": "", "name": null, "seo": null, "sub": null}, "keywords": [], "pub_date": "2009-07-13T08:35:06+0000", "document_type": "article", "news_desk": "Business", "section_name": "Business Day", "byline": {"original": "By Dealbook", "person": [{"firstname": "Dealbook", "middlename": null, "lastname": "", "qualifier": null, "title": null, "role": "reported", "organization": "", "rank": 1}], "organization": null}, "type_of_material": "News", "_id": "nyt://article/be5f2f70-aecc-5f53-904d-724eefdb221d", "word_count": 1144, "uri": "nyt://article/be5f2f70-aecc-5f53-904d-724eefdb221d"}

{"abstract": "The Chinese authorities have detained or questioned at least seven Chinese steel industry executives in a broadening corruption investigation connected to the detentions last week of four employees of the mining giant Rio Tinto.", "web_url": "https://dealbook.nytimes.com/2009/07/14/china-broadens-steel-inquiry-beyond-rio-tinto/", "snippet": "The Chinese authorities have detained or questioned at least seven Chinese steel industry executives in a broadening corruption investigation connected to the detentions last week of four employees of the mining giant Rio Tinto.", "lead_paragraph": "The Chinese authorities have detained or questioned at least seven Chinese steel industry executives in a broadening corruption investigation connected to the detentions last week of four employees of the mining giant Rio Tinto, state-controlled news media reported Monday.", "source": "The New York Times", "multimedia": [], "headline": {"main": "China Broadens Steel Inquiry Beyond Rio Tinto", "kicker": "DealBook", "content_kicker": null, "print_headline": "", "name": null, "seo": null, "sub": null}, "keywords": [], "pub_date": "2009-07-14T09:30:34+0000", "document_type": "article", "news_desk": "Business", "section_name": "Business Day", "byline": {"original": "By Dealbook", "person": [{"firstname": "Dealbook", "middlename": null, "lastname": "", "qualifier": null, "title": null, "role": "reported", "organization": "", "rank": 1}], "organization": null}, "type_of_material": "News", "_id": "nyt://article/3e22acb4-c510-5465-9389-89afd149ea7c", "word_count": 693, "uri": "nyt://article/3e22acb4-c510-5465-9389-89afd149ea7c"}

{"abstract": "Long before four employees of the Anglo-Australian mining giant Rio Tinto were detained in Shanghai last week, people working in China\u2019s steel industry were complaining about bribery, deceit and a system turned rotten.", "web_url": "https://dealbook.nytimes.com/2009/07/15/somethings-rotten-in-chinese-steel-industry/", "snippet": "Long before four employees of the Anglo-Australian mining giant Rio Tinto were detained in Shanghai last week, people working in China\u2019s steel industry were complaining about bribery, deceit and a system turned rotten.", "lead_paragraph": "Long before four employees of the British-Australian mining giant Rio Tinto were detained in Shanghai last week on suspicion of stealing state secrets, people working in China\u2019s steel industry were complaining about bribery, deceit and a system turned rotten, The New York Times\u2019s David Barboza writes.", "source": "The New York Times", "multimedia": [], "headline": {"main": "Something\u2019s Rotten in Chinese Steel Industry", "kicker": "DealBook", "content_kicker": null, "print_headline": "", "name": null, "seo": null, "sub": null}, "keywords": [], "pub_date": "2009-07-15T08:44:49+0000", "document_type": "article", "news_desk": "Business", "section_name": "Business Day", "byline": {"original": "By Dealbook", "person": [{"firstname": "Dealbook", "middlename": null, "lastname": "", "qualifier": null, "title": null, "role": "reported", "organization": "", "rank": 1}], "organization": null}, "type_of_material": "News", "_id": "nyt://article/f71bfed2-8de2-5f92-8096-0faed6d6c969", "word_count": 800, "uri": "nyt://article/f71bfed2-8de2-5f92-8096-0faed6d6c969"}

{"abstract": "China stepped up its campaign against the Anglo-Australian mining giant Rio Tinto, saying the company had bribed virtually every one of China\u2019s big steel makers.", "web_url": "https://dealbook.nytimes.com/2009/07/16/rio-tinto-gave-bribes-to-many-china-says/", "snippet": "China stepped up its campaign against the Anglo-Australian mining giant Rio Tinto, saying the company had bribed virtually every one of China\u2019s big steel makers.", "lead_paragraph": "China stepped up its campaign against the Anglo-Australian mining giant Rio Tinto on Wednesday, saying the company had bribed virtually every one of China\u2019s big steel makers, The New York Times\u2019s David Barboza writes.", "source": "The New York Times", "multimedia": [], "headline": {"main": "Rio Tinto Bribed Most Big Steel Makers, China Says", "kicker": "DealBook", "content_kicker": null, "print_headline": "", "name": null, "seo": null, "sub": null}, "keywords": [], "pub_date": "2009-07-16T08:51:48+0000", "document_type": "article", "news_desk": "Business", "section_name": "Business Day", "byline": {"original": "By Dealbook", "person": [{"firstname": "Dealbook", "middlename": null, "lastname": "", "qualifier": null, "title": null, "role": "reported", "organization": "", "rank": 1}], "organization": null}, "type_of_material": "News", "_id": "nyt://article/a20efb41-b3ee-5d51-9157-fa379956ab85", "word_count": 996, "uri": "nyt://article/a20efb41-b3ee-5d51-9157-fa379956ab85"}

{"abstract": "A small-business owner who travels frequently to Brazil has learned the country\u2019s secrets and even enjoys the flight.", "web_url": "https://www.nytimes.com/2009/12/01/business/01flier.html", "snippet": "A small-business owner who travels frequently to Brazil has learned the country\u2019s secrets and even enjoys the flight.", "lead_paragraph": "I\u2019VE been flying since I was a child. I was only 8 years old when I had my first solo flight to Europe. I had to wear my passport around my neck, and I always got a lot of attention from the flight attendants. {"abstract": "The Wuhan Iron & Steel Group, a Chinese steelmaker, agreed to pay $400 million for a stake in Brazil\u2019s MMX Mineracao e Metalicos to broaden its supply of iron ore.", "web_url": "https://www.nytimes.com/2009/12/01/business/global/01fobriefs-CHINESEBUYST_BRF.html", "snippet": "The Wuhan Iron & Steel Group, a Chinese steelmaker, agreed to pay $400 million for a stake in Brazil\u2019s MMX Mineracao e Metalicos to broaden its supply of iron ore.", "lead_paragraph": "The Wuhan Iron & Steel Group, a Chinese steelmaker, agreed to pay $400 million for a stake in Brazil\u2019s MMX Mineracao e Metalicos to broaden its supply of iron ore. Wuhan Steel, based in Hubei province, will appoint two board members to MMX and become the second-biggest shareholder of the Brazilian company with a 21.52 percent stake, the Chinese company said. MMX, which is based in Rio de Janeiro, has a market value of 3.7 billion reais ($2.1 billion), according to Bloomberg data. China, the world\u2019s biggest steel producer, is investing in iron-ore projects globally to reduce dependence on Vale, the Rio Tinto Group and BHP Billiton. Wuhan Iron and EBX, MMX\u2019s holding company, also signed an accord to build a steel plant in Brazil, said a Wuhan Steel spokesman, Bai Fang. {"abstract": "With the genie of state intervention already out of the bottle, shareholders of the Brazilian mining giant Vale should prepare for their interests to come second.", "web_url": "https://www.nytimes.com/2011/04/04/business/04views.html", "snippet": "With the genie of state intervention already out of the bottle, shareholders of the Brazilian mining giant Vale should prepare for their interests to come second.", "lead_paragraph": "Last week\u2019s ouster of the chief executive of Vale, the mining giant based in Rio de Janeiro, sends a terrible signal to the markets about the Brazilian government\u2019s intentions. The executive, Roger Agnelli, resisted the state\u2019s designs to push the $180 billion company into lower-return, if labor-intensive, activities. With President Dilma Rousseff\u2019s government forcing his departure, investors must brace for a strategy that favors jobs over profit \u2014 in the fashion of Pemex instead of BHP Billiton.", "print_section": "B", "print_page": "2", "source": "The New York Times", "multimedia": [{"rank": 0, "subtype": "jumbo", "caption": null, "credit": null, "type": "image", "url": "images/2011/04/04/business/04views/04views-jumbo.jpg", "height": 549, "width": 1024, "subType": "jumbo", "crop_name": "jumbo", "legacy": {}}], "headline": {"main": "Lesson in Being a State Company", "kicker": "Reuters Breakingviews", "content_kicker": null, "print_headline": "Lesson in Being A State Company", "name": null, "seo": null, "sub": null}, "keywords": [{"name": "organizations", "value": "Federal Reserve System", "rank": 1, "major": "N"}, {"name": "persons", "value": "Cohn, Gary D", "rank": 2, "major": "N"}, {"name": "organizations", "value": "Financial Crisis Inquiry Commission", "rank": 3, "major": "N"}, {"name": "organizations", "value": "Goldman Sachs Group Inc", "rank": 4, "major": "N"}, {"name": "subject", "value": "Appointments and Executive Changes", "rank": 5, "major": "N"}], "pub_date": "2011-04-04T02:29:52+0000", "document_type": "article", "news_desk": "Business", "section_name": "Business Day", "byline": {"original": "By Rob Cox and Agnes T. {"abstract": "The Olympus board\u2019s decision to fire Michael C. Woodford after only two weeks shows that change was sorely needed.", "web_url": "https://www.nytimes.com/2011/10/18/business/olympus-chief-goes-but-push-for-reform-goes-on.html", "snippet": "The Olympus board\u2019s decision to fire Michael C. Woodford after only two weeks shows that change was sorely needed.", "lead_paragraph": "Olympus\u2019s embarrassing decision to dump its British chief executive two weeks after naming him to the job shows that reform in Japan is a slow and fitful process. The executive, Michael C. Woodford, was brought in to clean house at the company, and became one of Japan\u2019s handful of foreign corporate bosses. That the board decided to fire him so soon shows the medicine was distasteful. {"abstract": "Chevron faces fines of as much as $83 million for an oil spill this month off the coast of Rio de Janeiro, the authorities said Monday.", "web_url": "https://www.nytimes.com/2011/11/22/business/energy-environment/brazil-chevron-faces-fines-of-83-million-in-oil-spill.html", "snippet": "Chevron faces fines of as much as $83 million for an oil spill this month off the coast of Rio de Janeiro, the authorities said Monday.", "lead_paragraph": " Chevron faces fines of as much as $83 million for an  oil spill this month off the coast of Rio de Janeiro, the authorities said Monday. The fines reflect the government\u2019s anger over Chevron\u2019s handling of the spill. Chevron may also face additional fines and legal penalties, officials said. Haroldo Lima, head of the National Petroleum Agency, said the spill could complicate Chevron\u2019s hopes of gaining access to new offshore exploration areas. Federal investigators said Chevron employees might also face prison terms. Chevron said in a statement that it had not yet received official notice of any fines and would respond if it did. {"abstract": "Robert Friedland, one of Canada\u2019s most prominent mining developers, resigned as chief executive of Ivanhoe Mines, ending a long-running battle between the executive and Rio Tinto.", "web_url": "https://dealbook.nytimes.com/2012/04/18/mining-chief-resigns-as-part-of-deal-with-rio-tinto/", "snippet": "Robert Friedland, one of Canada\u2019s most prominent mining developers, resigned as chief executive of Ivanhoe Mines, ending a long-running battle between the executive and Rio Tinto.", "lead_paragraph": "OTTAWA \u2014 Robert Friedland, one of Canada\u2019s most prominent mining developers, resigned as chief executive of Ivanhoe Mines on Wednesday as part of a $1.8 billion equity financing agreement with Rio Tinto, the company\u2019s major shareholder.", "source": "The New York Times", "multimedia": [], "headline": {"main": "Mining Chief Resigns as Part of Deal With Rio Tinto", "kicker": "DealBook", "content_kicker": null, "print_headline": "", "name": null, "seo": null, "sub": null}, "keywords": [{"name": "subject", "value": "Mines and Mining", "rank": 3, "major": "N"}, {"name": "subject", "value": "Suspensions, Dismissals and Resignations", "rank": 4, "major": "N"}, {"name": "persons", "value": "Friedland, Robert Martin", "rank": 5, "major": "N"}, {"name": "organizations", "value": "IVANHOE MINES LTD", "rank": 6, "major": "N"}, {"name": "organizations", "value": "Rio Tinto PLC", "rank": 7, "major": "N"}], "pub_date": "2012-04-18T17:18:00+0000", "document_type": "article", "news_desk": "", "section_name": "Business Day", "byline": {"original": "By Ian Austen", "person": [{"firstname": "Ian", "middlename": null, "lastname": "Austen", "qualifier": null, "title": null, "role": "reported", "organization": "", "rank": 1}], "organization": null}, "type_of_material": "News", "_id": "nyt://article/a7fdbd94-d8f2-5ddf-acbc-2629f5afc7b5", "word_count": 450, "uri": "nyt://article/a7fdbd94-d8f2-5ddf-acbc-2629f5afc7b5"}

{"abstract": "New regulations in Mongolia could stifle a deal to develop the Oyu Tolgoi mine, the world\u2019s biggest new source of copper, and hurt the country\u2019s broader economy.", "web_url": "https://dealbook.nytimes.com/2012/12/10/boom-in-mongolia-deflates-after-deal-that-started-it-is-threatened-2/", "snippet": "New regulations in Mongolia could stifle a deal to develop the Oyu Tolgoi mine, the world\u2019s biggest new source of copper, and hurt the country\u2019s broader economy.", "lead_paragraph": "ULAN BATOR, Mongolia \u2014 The concept of a \u201cblue sky country\u201d has become almost a clich\u00e9 in presentations about Mongolia, the world\u2019s fastest-growing economy last year. "Bank of America continues to work through mortgage woes stemming from its acquisition of Countrywide Financial. The bank reported a widely expected 63 percent drop in fourth-quarter profit after settling claims over its mortgage business. The earnings of $732 million amounted to 3 cents a share, narrowly beating estimates of 2 cents a share, based on analysts surveyed by Thomson Reuters. The bank\u2019s quarterly revenue was down about 25 percent, to $18.7 billion. {"abstract": "BHP Billiton, the world\u2019s largest mining company, sits atop a sector that is deeply out of favor with investors, and it is aggressively curtailing its spending in hopes of winning them over.", "web_url": "https://dealbook.nytimes.com/2013/08/08/after-going-all-in-during-mining-boom-bhp-cuts-its-ambitions/", "snippet": "BHP Billiton, the world\u2019s largest mining company, sits atop a sector that is deeply out of favor with investors, and it is aggressively curtailing its spending in hopes of winning them over.", "lead_paragraph": "BHP Billiton, the world\u2019s largest mining company, was willing to spend big in early 2012. It was building new mines and upgrading old ones, at a cost of $18 billion. It considered a potential expansion of its copper and uranium mine, Olympic Dam, which could have cost as much as $20 billion. It proposed a deepwater extension of Port Hedland, its iron ore port, an estimated $10 billion or more.", "source": "The New York Times", "multimedia": [], "headline": {"main": "After Going All In During Mining Boom, BHP Cuts Its Ambitions", "kicker": "DealBook", "content_kicker": null, "print_headline": "", "name": null, "seo": null, "sub": null}, "keywords": [{"name": "subject", "value": "Commodities", "rank": 1, "major": "N"}, {"name": "subject", "value": "Metals and Minerals", "rank": 2, "major": "N"}, {"name": "subject", "value": "Mines and Mining", "rank": 3, "major": "N"}, {"name": "persons", "value": "Kloppers, Marius", "rank": 4, "major": "N"}, {"name": "persons", "value": "Mackenzie, Andrew S", "rank": 5, "major": "N"}, {"name": "organizations", "value": "Anglo American Corp", "rank": 6, "major": "N"}, {"name": "organizations", "value": "BHP Billiton PLC", "rank": 7, "major": "N"}, {"name": "organizations", "value": "Rio Tinto PLC", "rank": 8, "major": "N"}, {"name": "organizations", "value": "Vale S A", "rank": 9, "major": "N"}, {"name": "glocations", "value": "Australia", "rank": 10, "major": "N"}], "pub_date": "2013-08-08T18:38:59+0000", "document_type": "article", "news_desk": "", "section_name": "Business Day", "byline": {"original": "By William MacNamara", "person": [{"firstname": "William", "middlename": null, "lastname": "MacNamara", "qualifier": null, "title": null, "role": "reported", "organization": "", "rank": 1}], "organization": null}, "type_of_material": "News", "_id": "nyt://article/b12342db-09df-52e7-8d85-992a9c6e2c4a", "word_count": 1196, "uri": "nyt://article/b12342db-09df-52e7-8d85-992a9c6e2c4a"}

Geithner on the hot seat. | Glencore\u2019s chief pursues Rio Tinto.", "web_url": "https://dealbook.nytimes.com/2014/10/08/morning-agenda-another-twist-in-allergan-battle/", "snippet": "Valeant and Pershing Square are planning to raise their offer for Allergan. | Profit at Goldman less easy to find. | A.I.G. trial puts Timothy F. Geithner on the hot seat. | Glencore\u2019s chief pursues Rio Tinto.", "lead_paragraph": "VALEANT TO RAISE ALLERGAN BID | Valeant Pharmaceuticals and Pershing Square Capital Management are said to be planning to raise their offer to acquire the Botox maker Allergan by $15 a share, David Gelles writes in DealBook. The bump in the offer price, to more than $191 a share, or nearly $60 billion in cash and stock, signals yet another twist in the year\u2019s longest and most contentious takeover battle. It could affect the thinking of Allergan\u2019s board, which is working to strike other deals that would thwart the attempted takeover by Valeant and Pershing Square. And it could sway Allergan shareholders, who are preparing for a special meeting in December at which they will have the chance to vote out a majority of the Allergan board.", "source": "The New York Times", "multimedia": [], "headline": {"main": "Morning Agenda: Another Twist in Allergan Battle", "kicker": "DealBook", "content_kicker": null, "print_headline": "", "name": null, "seo": null, "sub": null}, "keywords": [], "pub_date": "2014-10-08T11:44:57+0000", "document_type": "article", "news_desk": "Business", "section_name": "Business Day", "byline": {"original": "By Sydney Ember", "person": [{"firstname": "Sydney", "middlename": null, "lastname": "Ember", "qualifier": null, "title": null, "role": "reported", "organization": "", "rank": 1}], "organization": null}, "type_of_material": "News", "_id": "nyt://article/a6c8886b-b73b-5771-933a-883730d89b40", "word_count": 2057, "uri": "nyt://article/a6c8886b-b73b-5771-933a-883730d89b40"}]

{"abstract": "A conga line of truth-tellers and liars. Can you tell who\u2019s lying and who\u2019s telling the truth?", "web_url": "https://wordplay.blogs.nytimes.com/2014/11/10/truth-2/", "snippet": "A conga line of truth-tellers and liars. Can you tell who\u2019s lying and who\u2019s telling the truth?", "lead_paragraph": "Our puzzle this week was suggested by Marco Moriconi, a regular Numberplay contributor and professor of physics at the Universidade Federal Fluminense, in Niteroi, Rio de Janeiro. (He also writes a monthly math column for the Brazilian national science magazine, Ci\u00eancia Hoje (Science Today), called Qual o Problema, or \u201cWhat\u2019s the Problem?\u201d). Dr. Moriconi found this week\u2019s puzzle in a blog by its creator, Roy Cook, a professor of philosophy at the University of Minnesota who tells how he momentarily stumped the famous paradox master Raymond Smullyan with the challenge. (Check out Dr. Cook\u2019s recently-published Paradoxes and Dr. Smullyan\u2019s Beginner\u2019s Guide to Mathematical Logic, selected by Amazon as a favorite book of 2014.)", "source": "The New York Times", "multimedia": [], "headline": {"main": "Truth-Tellers and Liars", "kicker": "Wordplay", "content_kicker": null, "print_headline": "", "name": null, "seo": null, "sub": null}, "keywords": [{"name": "subject", "value": "Mathematics", "rank": 7, "major": "N"}, {"name": "subject", "value": "Puzzles", "rank": 8, "major": "N"}, {"name": "persons", "value": "Gosper, Bill", "rank": 9, "major": "N"}, {"name": "glocations", "value": "Rio de Janeiro (Brazil)", "rank": 10, "major": "N"}], "pub_date": "2014-11-10T17:00:59+0000", "document_type": "article", "news_desk": "Business", "section_name": "Crosswords & Games", "byline": {"original": "By Gary Antonick", "person": [{"firstname": "Gary", "middlename": null, "lastname": "Antonick", "qualifier": null, "title": null, "role": "reported", "organization": "", "rank": 1}], "organization": null}, "type_of_material": "News", "_id": "nyt://article/61a0084e-a050-5850-84ea-1951761262b7", "word_count": 1370, "uri": "nyt://article/61a0084e-a050-5850-84ea-1951761262b7"}

{"abstract": "Kroton Educacional has agreed to sell its learning unit Uniasselvi to the Carlyle Group and the Brazilian investment firm Vinci Partners for $284.6 million.", "web_url": "https://www.nytimes.com/2015/10/27/business/dealbook/carlyle-group-and-vinci-partners-buy-brazilian-education-business.html", "snippet": "Kroton Educacional has agreed to sell its learning unit Uniasselvi to the Carlyle Group and the Brazilian investment firm Vinci Partners for $284.6 million.", "lead_paragraph": "RIO DE JANEIRO \u2014 Kroton Educacional S.A. has agreed to sell its learning unit Uniasselvi, to the Carlyle Group and the Brazilian investment firm Vinci Partners for 1.105 billion Brazilian reais, or $284.6 million, it said in a filing with the country\u2019s securities regulator on Monday.", "source": "The New York Times", "multimedia": [], "headline": {"main": "Carlyle Group and Vinci Partners Buy Brazilian Education Business", "kicker": null, "content_kicker": null, "print_headline": "", "name": null, "seo": null, "sub": null}, "keywords": [{"name": "subject", "value": "Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures", "rank": 1, "major": "N"}, {"name": "subject", "value": "Private Equity", "rank": 2, "major": "N"}, {"name": "organizations", "value": "Carlyle Group LP", "rank": 3, "major": "N"}, {"name": "glocations", "value": "Brazil", "rank": 4, "major": "N"}], "pub_date": "2015-10-26T18:12:29+0000", "document_type": "article", "news_desk": "Business", "section_name": "Business Day", "subsection_name": "DealBook", "byline": {"original": "By Vinod Sreeharsha", "person": [{"firstname": "Vinod", "middlename": null, "lastname": "Sreeharsha", "qualifier": null, "title": null, "role": "reported", "organization": "", "rank": 1}], "organization": null}, "type_of_material": "News", "_id": "nyt://article/d6d203bf-44e0-5915-865e-425a01b5faf5", "word_count": 428, "uri": "nyt://article/d6d203bf-44e0-5915-865e-425a01b5faf5"}

{"abstract": "The Australian bank\u2019s new fund comes as opportunities are seen for foreign investors in infrastructure projects.", "web_url": "https://www.nytimes.com/2015/11/06/business/dealbook/macquarie-sets-up-brazil-infrastructure-fund.html", "snippet": "The Australian bank\u2019s new fund comes as opportunities are seen for foreign investors in infrastructure projects.", "lead_paragraph": "RIO DE JANEIRO \u2014 The Macquarie Group, the Australian investment bank, has raised over 600 million reais, or $159 million, from Brazilian investors and is nearing a first close for its debut Brazil infrastructure fund, according to a person briefed on the bank\u2019s plans.", "source": "The New York Times", "multimedia": [], "headline": {"main": "Macquarie Sets Up Brazil Infrastructure Fund", "kicker": null, "content_kicker": null, "print_headline": "", "name": null, "seo": null, "sub": null}, "keywords": [{"name": "subject", "value": "Foreign Investments", "rank": 1, "major": "N"}, {"name": "subject", "value": "Venture Capital", "rank": 2, "major": "N"}, {"name": "organizations", "value": "Macquarie Group", "rank": 3, "major": "N"}, {"name": "glocations", "value": "Brazil", "rank": 4, "major": "N"}], "pub_date": "2015-11-06T01:57:14+0000", "document_type": "article", "news_desk": "Business", "section_name": "Business Day", "subsection_name": "DealBook", "byline": {"original": "By Vinod Sreeharsha", "person": [{"firstname": "Vinod", "middlename": null, "lastname": "Sreeharsha", "qualifier": null, "title": null, "role": "reported", "organization": "", "rank": 1}], "organization": null}, "type_of_material": "News", "_id": "nyt://article/c63d934e-fb55-5a7c-9275-a0e87253f38a", "word_count": 407, "uri": "nyt://article/c63d934e-fb55-5a7c-9275-a0e87253f38a"}

It was also\u00a0a nice surprise\u00a0to find\u00a0Karen Crouse\u2019s\u00a0story about\u00a0Bruce Gemmell, an old college teammate of mine and current coach of swimmer\u00a0Katie Ledecky. {"abstract": "Nubank, a Brazilian start-up, also received backing from Peter Thiel\u2019s Founders Fund and other venture capitalists as investors flock to South America.", "web_url": "https://www.nytimes.com/2016/12/07/business/dealbook/dst-global-nubank.html", "snippet": "Nubank, a Brazilian start-up, also received backing from Peter Thiel\u2019s Founders Fund and other venture capitalists as investors flock to South America.", "lead_paragraph": "RIO DE JANEIRO \u2014 DST Global, the investment firm started by a Russian venture capitalist, Yuri Milner, has led an $80 million private investment in a Brazilian start-up called Nubank, the company is expected to announce this week.
